Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:17AM marbletop wrote: Hi Ladies, It is standard where I go to have a mammogram once a year and a MRI once a year. So I get my Mammogram in February and my MRI in August. I believe an MRI will not pick up Microcalcifications , but it is very sensitive and will pick up other small suspicious areas more than a Mammogram. I have to be honest, I get terrified every time I have to have a check up. I was diagnosed four years ago and still get freaked out. Good luck to you all. Cellist
Posts.Title: advocating for an MRI instead of mammography LtotheK Sandy105

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2011 02:24PM marbletop wrote: My oncologist says as long as the test in in normal range, don't worry. These markers can vary and also with changing labs. . My oncologist doesn't do the CEA but does the CA-15 and my numbers always vary a couple of points. It's scary when numbers change , I don't like it either. I too had IDC, Stage 1 in 2007. Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: CEA level went from 1.3 to 2.4 - should I be worried? Godlistens Godlistens

Posts.Content: marbletop wrote: I have yearly transvaginal ultrasounds with Doppler . This year the doctor saw an area in the iliac area. there is no flow or or any abnormal flow. he thinks it's a lymph node. They want me to do it again in 2 months. My fear is that this could be breast cancer mets. Five years ago I was diagnosed stage 1, 0 nodes, radiation and arimadex. Has anyone encountered this with there breast cancer? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: transvaginal ultrasound and Doppler marbletop marbletop

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 03:38PM marbletop wrote: Hello Linda, Thank you for your input. I totally agree with you about this disease. Tomorrow I see my medical oncologist and of course will get her take on my ultrasound. I too worry extensively when something shows up on a test. I hope your cat scan comes out clean . They are just being super careful because of our cancer history. iThe radiologist also found a sliver of fluid on my endometrium cavity and I too am post menopausal . It's to my understanding that if there is abnormal flow to the area, they are concerned about malignancy. Anyway, good luck with your cat scan results. I know how you feel with the waiting! Marble top

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 03:55PM marbletop wrote: Vascular invasion, I believe means if cancer cells got into the blood vessels of the breast area. It is one of the tests that are on your pathology report. ,I believe this issomething your medical oncologist will take into account when he or she reads report to decide the best treatment for your case.
